This creates a high base rate for record temperatures. (2) We may be transitioning from El Niño conditions, which typically boost global temperatures, toward neutral or La Niña conditions. The lack of information is significant - if May 2025 were dramatically warm, preliminary reports would likely be available. (4) The previous May record is likely from very recent years (2023 or 2024), making it a high bar to exceed. My forecast is not higher because I lack specific data suggesting May 2025 was exceptionally warm, and because the transition away from El Niño could moderate temperatures. My forecast is not lower because the recent trend has been very strong, the long-term warming signal is clear, and base rates from recent years suggest roughly 40-50% of months break records. I would update higher if preliminary NOAA data or reports suggested May 2025 was exceptionally warm globally.
